description: [Status: stable] [Name: mutable-fromkeys-value] [Message: Do not pass mutable objects as values to dict.fromkeys] What it does Checks for mutable objects passed as a value argument to dict.fromkeys. Why is this bad? All values in the dictionary created by the dict.fromkeys method refer to the same instance of the provided object. If that object is modified, all values are modified, which can lead to unexpected behavior. For example, if the empty list ([]) is provided as the default value, all values in the dictionary will use the same list; as such, appending to any one entry will append to all entries. Instead, use a comprehension to generate a dictionary with distinct instances of the default value. Example cities = dict.fromkeys(["UK", "Poland"], []) cities["UK"].append("London") cities["Poland"].append("Poznan") print(cities) # {'UK': ['London', 'Poznan'], 'Poland': ['London', 'Poznan']} Use instead: cities = {country: [] for country in ["UK", "Poland"]} cities["UK"].append("London") cities["Poland"].append("Poznan") print(cities) # {'UK': ['London'], 'Poland': ['Poznan']} Fix safety This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as the edit will change the behavior of the program by using a distinct object for every value in the dictionary, rather than a shared mutable instance. In some cases, programs may rely on the previous behavior.
